title: 107_hr5241
content: The Act titled "Lifespan Respite Care Act of 2002" amends the Public Health Service Act by adding a new section on Lifespan Respite Care. This section includes findings and purposes related to respite care services. Congress finds that an estimated 26,000,000 individuals in the United States care for adult family members or friends who are chronically ill, disabled, or terminally ill, 18,000,000 children have chronic conditions requiring caregiver supervision, and 6,000,000 children live with relatives due to parental inability or unwillingness to care for them. Approximately 165,000 children with disabilities live with foster care parents in the United States, while nearly 4,000,000 individuals of all ages with mental retardation or developmental disabilities reside with their families. Additionally, around 25 percent of the nation's elders have multiple chronic disabling conditions, requiring assistance with daily needs. Approximately 600,000 Americans die at home each year, with many relying on extensive family support. Approximately 600,000 Americans die at home each year, with many relying on extensive family caregiving before their deaths. 42 percent of individuals in the United States needing daily living assistance are under age 65, and there are insufficient resources to replace family caregivers with paid workers. Replacing family caregivers with paid services would cost approximately $200 billion annually, and the caregiver role can result in substantial emotional, physical, and financial hardship. Approximately 75 percent of family caregivers are women and often struggle to find information on available respite care programs. These programs are insufficient to meet the needs of family caregivers, especially those caring for the elderly, leaving many without adequate support. Limited availability and difficulty in recruiting for respite care programs further compound the challenges faced by family caregivers. The purposes of this title are to encourage States to establish respite care programs, improve information dissemination to family caregivers, provide respite care services, and promote innovative approaches to respite care delivery and worker recruitment. The purposes of this title include supporting respite care worker and volunteer recruitment and training programs, training programs for family caregivers, evaluative research on effective respite care services, and promoting dissemination of results and findings related to respite care delivery and caregiver strain. The curr_chunk focuses on respite care delivery, family caregiver strain, and training programs for family caregivers to make informed decisions about respite care services. The curr_chunk defines key terms related to respite care delivery and family caregiver training programs. The curr_chunk defines various conditions that are included in the term 'condition' for respite care delivery and family caregiver training programs. These conditions range from Alzheimer's disease and developmental disabilities to chronic illness and situations at high risk of abuse or neglect. The curr_chunk defines eligible recipients for respite care delivery and family caregiver training programs, including State agencies, public entities operating statewide, and private nonprofit organizations. The curr_chunk specifies that eligible recipients for respite care and family caregiver programs include private nonprofit organizations capable of operating statewide, political subdivisions with a population of at least 3,000,000 individuals, and recognized State respite coordinating agencies with demonstrated abilities to collaborate with other agencies and address caregiver issues. The curr_chunk discusses the importance of meaningful involvement of family members, caregivers, and care recipients in respite care services. It defines a family caregiver as an unpaid individual providing in-home care for a child or adult with special needs. Lifespan respite care is described as a coordinated system of community-based services for family caregivers. Respite care services provide temporary relief to family caregivers of individuals with special needs, regardless of age, race, or ethnicity. The term "respite care" refers to planned or emergency care when the caregiver is unable to provide care. The Secretary of Health and Human Services is referred to as the "Secretary," and "special need" is defined as the individual's specific requirements. The term "special need" refers to the particular needs of an individual requiring care or supervision due to a condition to meet basic needs or prevent harm. "SEC. 2803. LIFESPAN RESPITE CARE GRANTS AND COOPERATIVE AGREEMENTS." The section aims to expand respite care services for family caregivers, improve dissemination and coordination, and enhance access and quality of services to reduce caregiver strain. The Secretary is authorized to award grants to eligible recipients for this purpose. The Federal Lifespan Approach under this section aims to coordinate respite care services for family caregivers of individuals with special needs of all ages. Eligible recipients must submit an application to receive a grant or cooperative agreement for this purpose. Applicants seeking a grant or cooperative agreement must submit an application to the Secretary with required information, including understanding of respite care and family caregiver issues, and capacity for involving family members. The application for a grant or cooperative agreement must include information on respite care and family caregiver issues, as well as the capacity to involve family members. The description of the population of family caregivers should include details on their respite care needs. Collaboration with other agencies is also required. The grant application must include details on the population's respite care needs, existing services, coordination methods, and information dissemination. The grant application must include plans for respite care services, recruitment and training of caregivers, and collaboration with related services. The grant application must include plans for respite care services, recruitment, training of caregivers, and collaboration with related services, including public or private nonprofit entities. Participation of the population, including family caregivers and care recipients, in planning and implementation of respite care activities is essential. The proposed activities should maximize the use of available resources. The grant application must include plans for respite care services, recruitment, training of caregivers, and collaboration with related services. Activities should make use of Federal, State, and local funds, programs, contributions, reimbursements, personnel, and facilities. Respite care services for family caregivers in the applicant's State or locality should be improved through the use of funds. The grant application must include plans for respite care services, eligibility criteria for family caregivers, and monitoring of service quality and safety. This includes screening and ensuring necessary skills of respite care workers and volunteers. The grant application must include plans for respite care services, eligibility criteria for family caregivers, monitoring of service quality, and establishment of a review panel by the Secretary. The Secretary will establish a panel to review and evaluate grant applications, making recommendations for approval. The panel will meet as needed to expedite the review process. Grants or cooperative agreements will be awarded based on the panel's recommendations. The Secretary gives priority to applicants showing the greatest likelihood of implementing or enhancing lifespan respite care statewide when awarding grants or cooperative agreements. Grant or cooperative agreement funds must be used for the development of lifespan respite care. The grant funds prioritize the development of lifespan respite care at State and local levels, including services to meet unmet needs and evaluation of effectiveness. Eligible recipients can subcontract with public or nonprofit agencies. The Secretary awards grants or cooperative agreements for up to 5 years and may renew them. Funds must supplement, not supplant other Federal funds. The section should supplement, not supplant other Federal, State, and local funds for respite care services. The Secretary will award a grant to establish a National Resource Center on Lifespan Respite Care, which will maintain a national database, provide training and assistance to respite care programs, and offer information and education to the public. Authorization of appropriations is also included. Authorization of appropriations is included for carrying out the title.
